title: Intussusception
diagnosis_topic: Telescoping of bowel causing intermittent obstruction in infants
setup_script: A 12-month-old previously healthy boy presents with episodic crying and drawing up of the legs accompanied by vomiting. His mother notes a dark, jelly-like stool in his diaper.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 90/50 mmHg, HR 140 bpm, RR 30/min, Temp 37.8 C.
Child cries inconsolably then becomes lethargic between episodes; knees drawn to chest.
Sausage-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant; abdomen otherwise soft.
Target and pseudo-kidney signs consistent with ileocolic intussusception.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident places nasogastric tube and starts IV fluids
If resident performs pneumatic (air) enema reduction under radiologic guidance
dynamic_flow.reply: Successful reduction with passage of air into terminal ileum; child's symptoms resolve.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If enema fails or signs of perforation occur
dynamic_flow.reply: Proceed to surgical reduction and inspection for pathological lead point such as Meckel's diverticulum.
Risk of bowel ischemia and perforation increases.
CBC may show mild leukocytosis; type and cross for potential transfusion.
Approximately 10%, particularly within 24 hours; observe overnight.
Provide discharge instructions on signs of recurrence and when to return to hospital.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about typical lead points
dynamic_flow.reply: Meckel's diverticulum, polyps, lymphoma or Henoch-Schonlein purpura in older children.

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of intussusception via history, exam and ultrasound
Use of non-operative enema reduction as first-line treatment
Recognition of indications for surgical intervention
Prevention of delays that lead to ischemia and perforation
Post-reduction observation and parental education on recurrence
